title: Podcast: Wall Street’s $9 Billion China Rush
text:

Three numbers to start your day:

—this coming quarter. That’s according to a poll of major banks by The Wall Street Journal. The latest estimate for the U.S. oil benchmark, West Texas Intermediate, is virtually unchanged from last month’s forecast.

That outlook is a little surprising, given the turmoil in oil markets in early September. Back then, prices spiked after drones and missiles attacked oil infrastructure in Saudi Arabia. Prices quickly recovered and they recently made up all the lost ground. Especially after Saudi Arabia reportedly agreed to a partial cease-fire in Yemen, where a war has raged for four years.

Charles Scharf Has Served as a CEO for Six Years

—first at Visa and more recently at Bank of New York Mellon . Now, Scharf has been named the new chief executive of Wells Fargo (ticker: WFC). The bank had been rocked by a scandal over fake-accounts and Well Fargo promised to bring in an outsider to lead it. That was after regulators had criticized the bank’s response to the scandal.

Scharf is not only a onetime protege and top lieutenant of JPMorgan’s Jamie Dimon. He is also known for being able to rein in and run sprawling operations. Investors are hoping that Scharf will be able to lead an overhaul at Wells Fargo.

Annual Profits of $9 Billion Could Be up for Grabs

—in China’s financial sector. That’s according to Bloomberg.

The biggest Wall Street banks have been talking to regulators in Beijing about doing more business. And the Chinese government is opening up more of its market to global bank, even amid the U.S.-China trade war. Perhaps, progress on greater access to finance could even help ease tensions between the two countries.

Numbers by Barron’s is our daily podcast. Find out more here.

description: The outlook for oil prices in the coming quarter looks surprisingly unchanged. Investors are hoping that Charles Scharf will be able to lead an overhaul at Wells Fargo. And China is opening up more of its market to global banks.
